utterances: Hmm.
…attract them to your garden is to plant columbines.
There - and you'll also know if the columbines are in bloom that, likely, you're in the spring...
I have some - we have trumpet vines growing now.
I'm thinking that would help but…
Stranger, yes.
In the city, well, I've had them in my, you know, on my roof terrace in New York City.
They're here because it's migration.
They don't nest in New York City, but they'll nest in - not too far away from here.
You know, in the West Coast, there are other species.
In the mountain region, there are other species.
And, you know, they all have their own kind of favorite local plants.
And there are also a lot of exotic things that they'll feed on.
I would - I do encourage people to plant natives when they can.

But I think it's just, you know, keeping lots of flowers in bloom, particularly in the spring and fall when they're moving and, you know, also - even, you know, people forget that hummingbirds also eat other things.
They think of them as feeding on nectar, but, you know, I've watched hummingbirds picking out spiders from spider webs.
Really?
They will eat small insects also.
It takes a lot of protein to keep a body going, and sugar doesn't provide that.
And so, keeping a yard that's rich in wildlife — so, that it's not using too many pesticides, you know, just having lots of different stuff in your yard will always make it more accessible for birds.
Well, we've run out of time.
I want to thank all of my guests this hour.
Jeff Wells, author of the ""Birder's Conservation Handbook."" Glenn Phillips, executive director of New York City Audubon, and Tom McGuire, editor and publisher of eNature.
Thank you all for being with us today.
Thanks.
Pleasure is ours.
We're going to leave you today with a little bit of bird sounds, our own bird sounds.
Annette Heist, our senior producer, recorded this herself in the Pennsylvania Pocono Mountains.
These are the migrating red-winged blackbirds.
(Soundbite of red-winged blackbirds)
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
An hour ago, at a news conference in New York, former Senator George Mitchell described a flourishing drug culture in Major League Baseball from top to bottom.

Mitchell's long-awaited report identifies dozens of current and former players, including some of the best-known names in the sport, none bigger than home-run king Barry Bonds and seven-time Cy Young award winner Roger Clemens.
And Mitchell admits his list is by no means complete.

Blame also lies with management, which Mitchell said was slow to respond and cared more about economics than steroids, and with the players' union, which he said resisted testing and advised its members not to cooperate with this investigation.

The report, more than 400 pages in all, includes recommendations as well: an intensive education program, independent testing and an investigative arm that could consider documentary evidence of drug use as well as tests.
Baseball Commissioner Bud Selig, who asked Senator Mitchell to head this investigation almost two years ago, will respond a bit later this afternoon.
Donald Fehr, the head of the players' union, follows with a news conference of his own in New York this evening.
Later in this program, much of the Midwest is glazed in ice as sparkling wonderland that left many without even the promise of power for many days yet.
But first, steroids, baseball and the Mitchell report.
We're going to give you a chance to listen to some excerpts of the news conference, and we'll ask you to join the conversation a bit later.
With us now is our friend Alan Schwarz, who covered the news conference for The New York Times.
And, Alan, nice of you to be with us.
Oh, it's my pleasure, calling you here - from here at the Grand Hyatt in New York.
And what was the biggest surprise do you think to come out of the news conference today?
Well, the biggest surprise, certainly before the last 24 hours when everyone started talking about it, was the inclusion of Roger Clemens in the report.
And I always thought that talking about what names might be in the report prematurely was a little dangerous because, of course, you didn't know the context of - that the names would be mentioned.
And, well, the context in which Roger Clemens is mentioned and not to pick on him is really quite damning.
For instance, later that summer, Clemens asked McNamee to inject him with Winstrol, which Clemens supplied.
There are other comments like that.

McNamee stated that during this same time period, he also injected Clemens four to six times with human growth hormone he received from Radomski, McNamee being a former trainer of Clemens; Radomski being the former clubhouse guard for the Mets who, both of whom were the primary witnesses for this investigation.
Now, again, not to pick on Clemens that he is certainly the biggest relatively new name beyond Barry Bonds, beyond Gary Sheffield, beyond Jason Giambi, to which we're accustomed hearing.
And Miguel Tejada, another former most valuable player award winner, also named in the investigation, along with dozens of other players.
Some of whose names, as you suggested, we had heard and some we had not.
Let me as you, though, there was some question about George Mitchell's independence.
He is a director of the Boston Red Sox - that's a paid position - he is not part of ownership per se.
He didn't take any money from the Red Sox during this investigation.
But there were some who thought that he might so softly on his friend Bud Selig, the baseball commissioner.
Well, he certainly was not soft on Selig.
He made it clear that everybody involved - team management, the players' association, commissioners - he made very clear he said it and he hit it hard: commissioners.
And, of course, there was only one commissioner during this period.
Almost without exception, all current players declined my invitation and refused to meet or to talk with me.
Let's get some listeners involved in this conversation.
We're talking with Bill Littlefield, the host of it's ONLY A GAME.
He's with us from WBUR in Boston.
You think the deadline is phony?

and feel pride in his culture.

will seek revenge against the Iranians - the two nations face off in Los Angles on Sunday.

Mike Pesca, NPR News, New York.
